prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sensitivity requirement is determined by our experience in HD142527 in Cycle0, where we detected HCO+(4-3) inside the protoplanetary cavity, with a sensitivity of 10mJy/beam in 0.5km/s channels. Here we have extrapolated to the Cycle2 beam, as the relative sizes between Cycle2 beam and the source is comparable to that of the Cycle0 data in HD142527.
In order to make more efficient use of ALMA, we have deepened somewhat on the target sensitivity.
The high data rate is due to the acquisition of the line diagnostics, which are necessary in this proposal.

The sensitivity requirement is determined by our experience in HD142527 in Cycle0, where we detected HCO+(4-3) inside the protoplanetary cavity, with a sensitivity of 10mJy/beam in 0.5km/s channels. Here we have extrapolated to the Cycle2 beam, as the relative sizes between Cycle2 beam and the source is comparable to that of the Cycle0 data in HD142527.
In order to make more efficient use of ALMA, we have deepened somewhat on the target sensitivity.
The high datarate is due to the acquisition of the molecular line diagnostics, which are necessary to this proposal. Molecular gas in these disks is bound to be optically, and HCO+ has been detected previously, so the H13CO+ observation will allow opacity estimates (even upper limits)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Numerical simulations show that when giant planets form, they clear a radial gap in the protoplanetary disk. During this ‘transition’ phase, inside the gap, on-going planet accretion channels material from overdensities at the outer edge of the gap, into gap-crossing accretion streams. The amount of residual gas and small dust grains inside the gap is a decreasing function of planet mass.
The detection of such residual gas in cavities is a long-sought sign-post of planetary formation. In HD 142527, with the largest protoplanetary cavity, ALMA revealed non-Keplerian gas flows inside the cavity. The observation of gas kinematics inside the gaps of transition disks opens the exciting possibility of understanding the dynamical clearing phase of planet formation. However, observations of other transition disks at different orientations are needed to ascertain the nature of the cavity dynamics, and if they are indeed due to dynamical clearing. Here we propose to extend the results in HD 142527 by searching for residual gas in the largest protoplanatary cavities, and sample its kinematics in HCO+(4-3).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
